1572705629_1FXFTPnN5etVrX3KURv61vEEbEqay.body:
Trackers are used to locate peers. You cannot download using the BitTorrent protocol without trackers. Trackers may be centralized (e.g. http://www.opentrackr.org/announce) or distributed (using the DHT protocol, in which case each peer is also a tracker).
A .torrent file may contain a list of trackers, but it's optional. You can also modify the .torrent file to delete trackers or include new ones. A magnet URI (link) may also contain optional trackers - they are added to the URI as parameters using the "&tr=" prefix ("&" for appending a new parameter, and "tr" for specifying a tracker).
While the .torrent file contains "metadata" (cryptographic hash data) for the actual "content" (files to be downloaded by the torrent client), the magnet URI for torrents specifies metadata for the .torrent file (the BitTorrent info hash).
So, you use the magnet URI to obtain sufficient torrent information which eventually gets you the content.
You need trackers to obtain the torrent from magnet and to obtain the content from the torrent (either static servers, or dynamic peers using DHT/PeX).

Using a VPN is like choosing a different ISP - what your ISP knew about your Internet activities, now your VPN knows, and besides this, your ISP also knows you're using this particular VPN, even though it does not know exactly what you're using it for, as the connection to the VPN is usually encrypted. Depending on how bad the legislation is on your part of the world in which your ISP resides, a VPN can be an improvement (especially if you can pay using a more anonymous method), not much different, or even worse (don't forget, the connection speed is the minimum between your IPS's and your VPN's and the lag is the sum of both).

If you're looking for a bit more privacy when using BitTorrent, there are a few things to mention:
 - use an up-to-date BitTorrent client (preferably an open source one).
 - use an anonymous proxy like Tor at least for everything but peer-to-peer connections (client updates, DNS resolution, static tracker connections, RSS, searches, etc.), and make sure the BitTorrent client is actually aware and working with the proxy so it doesn't accidentally leak your IP anyway.
 - enable (or even enforce) encryption in your client for the BitTorrent protocol (though your ISP may deduce you're using torrents even with encryption, it may help avoiding throttling).

For a more hands-on approach, see this:
https://wiki.btguard.com/index.php/Tutorial:Proxy
They sell the proxy but you can replace it with your own. For example, if you already run ZeroNet over Tor, you already have a Socks5 proxy running on 127.0.0.1:49050 (to replace in the tutorial "proxy.btguard.com" with "127.0.0.1" and "1025" with "49050").

If you want to go all out, you can also proxy (like it's said in the tutorial) peer-to-peer connections, just know that it may slow the transfer to a crawl, especially if you're running over Tor. Also know that DHT and uTP work over UDP and won't be proxied, so you either disable them (along with UDP trackers) or use them directly outside the proxy.
In the end, don't forget that you never know who you're connecting to with BitTorrent and there have already been cases of entrapment with copyright holders seeding their own honey-potted content. You may try to mitigate this using block-lists (like iblocklist.com/lists) but it's not a foolproof solution.

1573007223_144CwRj8eynTUC9DtGHaNHR3wm9P2.body:
The single thread rating of your CPU is under 1500 (cpubenchmark.net/cpu.php?id=809) and below the minimum of 1600 (pcsx2.net/getting-started).
If you have a beafy Android system, you can try emulating with RetroArch using the Play! core.

It's not only about the complexity of original hardware of the consoles, but also about how well they are emulated on other platforms. Also, not all games perform the same. If you have the patience, you can try to tweak the emulator settings trading lower quality for better performance.

Here are a few things you can try:
techwhoop.com/fastest-setting-pcsx2
youtu.be/qXm5K_aaNts

1572891014_14g2gXnsZdEPShFJkGdh5W3eGXmKz.body:
There was recently a conference in Macedonia titled "ICT Innovations 2019 - Big Data Processing and Mining". It contains brief descriptions for a few research projects that may binterest you.

You can find some information about the book and buy it from here:
amazon.com/Innovations-2019-Data-Processing-Mining-ebook/dp/B07Z5ZQNQD

You can access the PDF file directly here:
sci-hub.se/10.1007/978-3-030-33110-8

Many publishers (Springer, Wiley, ACM, Elsevier, IEEE) gather research papers and offer online indexed libraries, some with open access but most under paid subscription (though you can peek at the latter freely through sci-hub).

1573600133_1G1TDPTXcSqZFi6eyZc4ccMeiLERL.body:
As was already mentioned, it's part of Firefox' initiative to implement measures against browser fingerprinting first introduced in version 41. Letterboxing is just one of the many features implemented.

In its current form, in the Tor Browser the screen starts at size 1000x1000 (if the monitor has the space) and resizes in 100 pixels increments.

If you want to disable this feature, you can go to "about:config" (in the address bar) and change "privacy.resistFingerprinting.letterboxing" to "false".

1574848015_144CwRj8eynTUC9DtGHaNHR3wm9P2.body:
Librem 5 (Linux instead of Android): puri.sm/products/librem-5

A LineageOS supported, bootloader unlocked, phone if you're up to flashing ROMs: download.lineageos.org

At least an Android One mobile phone to avoid carrier bloatware: android.com/one

> [mfs](#comment_59_1B8Nj3YZQSgw2aqhrHof5w73RpP6Xk2a7W): Do those of you who recommend Librem 5 actually have one?

I'll address this argument because I've heard it many times before.

Actually, I don't even own a phone. And if I were to be obligated to carry one, I would place a feature phone on the top of my list. I just didn't think it was appropriate to do it here due to the obvious lack in popularity.

I wouldnâ€™t presume to actually tell anyone what is best for them, just show some options I consider interesting. It may be better than starting your search entirely from zero (no pun intended).

And speaking of "recommendations", also know a bit about STDs, though never got the pleasure of having one myself (that I know of) and a bit about astronomy, though never been out there (yet).

Come to think of it, most of my clients pay me to solve for them problems I've never had.

1575162021_17UaTuxP639VqVnepbKXm14qsD8Fv.body:
Some old ThinkPad laptops along with some Chromebooks and MackBooks are compatible with Libreboot. They're pretty old though, and while Libreboot may be faster and more secure than the default OEM BIOS, it comes with its own quirks because they are kept in the dark about some hardware implementation aspects.
You can find the supported hardware here:
libreboot.org/docs/hardware/

There's also Coreboot which although allows for binary blobs, it has a larger compatibility list.
coreboot.org/status/board-status.html

Some offers from System76 and Purism may also be of interest to the privacy inclined user:
puri.sm/learn/avoiding-intel-amt
blog.system76.com/post/168050597573/system76-me-firmware-updates-plan
They apparently try to work around the issues with the Intel Management Engine.

Considering the overpricing of Intel processors and their speculative execution vulnerabilities it may be wiser to go AMD if you need a very modern system. AMD have their own Management Engine equivalent (the Platform Security Processor), but latest AGESA updates allow for (partially) disabling it (if you trust the wolf guarding the sheep). Intel doesn't even try to keep up appearances and you have to resort to undocumented procedures (like those used in unME11 or me_cleaner) that may result in bricking your hardware. AMD also suffers from Spectre vulnerabilities but not at the level of Meltdown of Intel processors and are cheaper at similar performance.

At least there are many more eyes doing static analysis nowadays (especially those with big budgets and a lot invested in "cloud" computing) looking for and reporting vulnerabilities that may make the manufacturers release updates for everybody, including laptop owners.

In the end, if I were to have to collaborate with my bio-weapon researcher buddies, and need the latest and greatest to run simulations, I'd air-gap a beefy modern system (maybe with the WiFi module entirely removed), saving the results on an optical disc before reading it on a secure (although older) laptop with Libreboot and a minimal Linux/BSD compiled from source and communicating the results.

Anyway, if you think ME/PSP are bad now, wait to see them shine in the new generation of 5G enabled laptops.
